Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Fog and the fire regime in southern California shrublands
Award.AbstractNarration:
For many Mediterranean regions around the world fire disturbance is important and can have important ecological and economic consequences. One of the primary controls on fire occurrence, behavior and size is the amount of water present in plants (called ?live fuel moisture?). When live fuel moisture is low, fires spread more. Although rainfall is thought to be the main determinant for plant water content, coastal California experiences seasonal fog during the late summer when drought is strongest. Plants in this region may be able to use fog as a water source which could alter their water content. This project seeks to understand this potential connection between fog and fire disturbance for coastal California. The first objective is to determine whether or not coastal shrubland plant species are using fog water. The proposed research utilizes natural differences in water isotopes between rain and fog to determine what type of water plants are using, and when. By tracking different sources of water uptake, this project can establish a link between fog and flammability of coastal ecosystems in California.
Understanding fire disturbance in Southern California is a high priority for science and industry alike. Live fuel moisture is a critical component of the National Fire Danger Rating System as well as numerous fire modeling efforts. This project will effectively inform the greater fire science community about the controls on fire disturbance in coastal California. It may also demonstrate the use of a novel water source for California shrub ecosystems. This is important for the field of plant ecology as fog water use in plants is a relatively new discovery. Overall, this study will be the first attempt to connect a rarely studied climatic event, fog, to local and regional scale disturbance patterns. The results from this study will enter the scientific discourse through publications and conference presentations at the local and international levels. The researchers have a strong commitment to involving undergraduates in research and mentoring them, especially underrepresented groups, through their college careers. In addition to mentoring undergraduates the investigators will continue to work with outreach programs for mentoring young scientists and with UCSB?s programs such as CAMP (California Alliance for Minority Participation) and the Research Mentorship Program, a program for exposing high school students to scientific research.

Fire is a widespread disturbance event that has had important ecological and evolutionary influences on species and ecosystems. One region with periodic fire disturbance is the Mediterranean-type climate region of California. With a climate characterized by cool, wet winters and prolonged summer drought, wildfire in these areas is typically high intensity and has dramatic ecological and economic consequences. While previous research has explored precipitation and extreme fire weather as predictors of fire patterns, studies have not considered clouds and fog as a potential influence on fire disturbance. These common climatic events along the coast of California may provide additional moisture for shrubs during the summer drought and reduce the flammability of plants.

The objectives of this study were to (1) determine fog water use in shrubs species during the summer drought and (2) improve our understanding of soil water evaporation as it relates to plant water uptake. Investigators and undergraduate assistants visited several field sites in Santa Barbara County for three summers (2011-2013) and collected water, plant and soil samples. Fog is hard to predict along the California coast and is also difficult to measure. The investigators and undergraduates built fog collectors to quantify fog deposition and determine the stable isotopic ratio of Oxygen and Hydrogen. The stable isotopic ratio of a water source acts as a tracer by which ecologists can determine water source use by plants. Samples from five plant species were simultaneously collected at these field sites from two different plant communities, chaparral and coastal sage scrub. Nathan Emery evaluated the fog record and selected particular date windows when fog deposition was high and detection of fog in plant stems was most likely to occur. These samples were analyzed for their stable isotopic ratio and entered into a mixing model to determine proportional fog water use.

Of the five shrub species evaluated, all showed fog water use during the summer drought. Certain species, however, used fog in greater proportions. The two drought-deciduous species, Artemisia californica and Salvia leucophylla, showed significant fog water use, especially during the late summer months. This is possibly explained by rooting depth as these two species have the shallowest rooting distributions of the five species. The coastal sage scrub community where A. californica and S. leucophylla grew was also the plant community that received the most late-summer fog. Also growing at the lower elevations was Baccharis pilularis, which did not appear to rely on fog as a water source. This species is known to have deep roots that tap into groundwater, enabling them to survive the summer drought. It is possible that B. pilularis does not have shallow roots that would be able to take up fog water.

The two chaparral species, Adenostoma fasciculatum and Ceanothus megacarpus, used relatively small proportions of fog in the early summer. However, low fog water use in these species is likely due to little fog deposition at elevation during the late summer months. In regions of higher fog deposition in chaparral, it is possible these species will opportunistically use fog water.

In addition to determining fog water use in several shrub species, this study sought to improve our understanding of soil water evaporation and isotopic mixing models.
